The person is Jewish because the inscription was found in a Jewish catacomb, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.5.3, pp. 46-7.
According to CIJ 362, ̓Ακονε could be the simple transcription of the Hebrew word הקנה (the zealot).
The transliteration is straightforward, see vol. 3, Introduction 2.4.2.2, p. 17.

Viellefond (Cestes, 17) claims he was certainly of Jewish descent because of his description of Jerusalem as τῆς ἀρχαίας πατρίδος κολωνίας Αἰλίας Καπιτωλίνης τῆς Παλαιστίνης ([my] ancient homeland the colony Aelia Capitolina of Palestine). However, see E. Habas (Rubin), “The Jewish Origin of Julius Africanus,” Journal of Jewish Studies 45 (1994) 86-91. If he was Jewish he certainly converted to Christianity, for he is an important Church Father. See for support, vol. 3, Introduction 6.1.6.3, p. 32.
These are his dates, see Introduction 7.1.
On this form see vol. 1, under Agrippa (1) L/M, p. 325.
In Greek – Φαινήσιος. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34.

The man is described in the inscription as θεοσεβής, see vol. 3, Introduction 6.1.6.1, p. 31. This, together with the provenance of the person – Phaene in Tranjordan (see vol. 3, Introduction 6.8, p. 54) – and the possibly Jewish symbols on it – palm branches (but see vol. 3, Introduction 6.3.2, p. 36) – have led the editors to suppose he may be Jewish. The name Agrippa was also popular with Jews, named after Jewish kings.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed, see vol. 3, Introduction 8.3, p. 60.

person.note: In Greek – Κανωθαί[́ω]ν ἐπ[ὶ]Συρίης. In Latin – Syri … Septimiano Canotha (Septimiana being the Latin name of the town). Canatha is situated in Transjordan. On such designations see vol. 1, Introduction 3.2.6, p. 34.

Oehler, MGWJ53 (1909) 449 writes “vielleicht ein Jude” probably based on the fact that he came to Gaul from Syria and had a Semitic name, but both criteria are not decisive. CIJ thought he was a pagan.
The name of the town “[S]eptimiano,” is after the emperor Septimius Severus. This is the year in which he died, see Introduction 7.1.

The inscription mentions pr[ovi]nc(iae) S(yriae) Pal(astinae) and thus postdates 135 CE.

There is nothing inherently pagan about this inscription, but neither is it particularly Jewish, and a military commander is hardly a typical Jewish profession. He is included in the corpus because his epitaph was found in Tiberias, a predominantly Jewish city.

The Jewish identity of this burial inscription was suggested by Roth-Gerson, Jews of Syria, no. xxxvi and is very tentative. Firstly it was pointed out that it was found near a Jewish inscription, but this is not a strong argument because both were found in the general cemetery of Tyre. Secondly, it was suggested that it has no Christian symbols to it, but this is an argument from silence and thus inconclusive. Thirdly it was pointed out that the profession of the deceased – jeweller (δακτυλιδάριος) – is typically Jewish, but this is an anachronistic statement and also inconclusive.
The inscription is dated according to the era of Tyre, see Introduction 7.5.4.3.

He is specifically described as abstaining from pork until he became sick and pork was prescribed as a remedy. He is described in the text as Σύρος τὸ γένος (Syrian by birth), which probably does not refer to Jews, see Stern, loc. cit. states “The Jews were not the only nation to abhor pork.”
The book in which he is mentioned appeard in this year, see Stern, GLAJJ, p. 671.

Eusebius informs us that he turned to Judaism at the time of prosecution against Christians. This is the only fitting time for this within the framework of Eusebius’ chronology, see Introduction 7.1.

However, see E. Habas (Rubin), “The Jewish Origin of Julius Africanus,” Journal of Jewish Studies 45 (1994) 86-91.
See previous note. If he was Jewish he certainly converted to Christianity, for he is an important Church Father. See for support, vol. 3, Introduction 6.1.6.3, p. 32.

These are the Names: Studies in Jewish Onomastics3 (Ramat Gan 2002) 73-92 (Hebrew). However I prefer M. Jacob’s observations (Die Institution des jüdischen Patriarchen [Tübingen 1995] 239) that this was a Roman name. Jacob’s observations (Die Institution des jüdischen Patriarchen [Tübingen 1995] 239) that this was a Roman name. Aurelius Victor writes of him: Et interea Iudaeorum sedition, qui Patricium nefarei in regni speciem sustelerant, oppressa (And meanwhile the revolt of the Jews, who impiously raised Patricius to royalty, was crushed). That Jews participated in this revolt is obvious, but the question whether it was a Jewish revolt, under a Jewish leader remains unclear, see previous note.
Presumably he was the Jewish leader of the revolt against Gallus. This is the date of the revolt, see Introduction 7.1.
